nodes.text: Increasing sleep among the urban poor produces measurable economic and wellbeing effects; specifically, the study asks whether experimentally increasing nighttime sleep or providing workplace naps causally improves productivity, cognition, preferences, and well-being

Context: Low-income adults in Chennai face environmental and psychological barriers (heat, noise, crowding, distress) that plausibly reduce sleep quantity and quality, making sleep a potentially important input to productivity and wellbeing

Method: Randomized controlled trial with 452 low-income adults in Chennai using continuous actigraphy, a one-month data-entry employment task, cross-randomized night-sleep interventions (devices+encouragement, devices+incentives) and a workplace nap treatment, with rich outcomes (productivity, labor supply, cognition, well-being, preferences)

Evidence (baseline): Objectively measured baseline sleep is severely constrained: average actual nighttime sleep ~5.5 hours/night, time in bed ~8 hours/night, sleep efficiency ~70%, ~31 awakenings/night; similar patterns in broader Chennai sample

Interventions: (a) Night-sleep bundle: loaned sleep devices, sleep-hygiene information and encouragement; (b) Night-sleep bundle + financial incentives (Rs.1 per added minute up to 120 min); (c) Workplace daily half-hour nap opportunity in comfortable nap stations; treatments cross-randomized

Result: Night-sleep interventions increased nighttime sleep by 27 minutes/night on average (33 min for incentives, 20 min for encouragement), driven entirely by increased time in bed (mean +38 minutes/night) with no improvement in sleep efficiency

Result: Nap treatment increased daytime sleep by about 14 minutes/day on average (∼93% of nap sessions resulted in sleep) and naps in office had higher sleep efficiency (~85%) than nighttime sleep at home

Measurement outcomes: Primary economic outcomes measured daily from the data-entry task were active typing time (labor supply), productivity (output per active hour), and earnings (attendance pay + performance pay); cognition, well-being, and preferences measured via incentivized tasks and surveys

Assumption/Design note: Treatments aimed to change sleep via two margins—time in bed and sleep efficiency—so observed changes identify whether participants can increase sleep quantity and/or quality in situ

Result/Evidence: Despite the 27-minute increase in nighttime sleep, pooled night-sleep treatments produced no detectable positive effects on the overall summary index (−0.01 SD), or on family indices for work, well-being, cognition, or preferences; night treatments lowered labor supply by ~9–10 minutes/day

Result/Evidence: Nap treatment improved the overall summary index by 0.12 SD (p≈.00), with significant positive effects on productivity (≈0.04 SD), psychological well-being (≈0.12 SD), lab cognition measures (≈0.08 SD) and attention at work (≈0.20 SD); naps reduced work time during nap slot producing mixed earnings effects depending on counterfactual

Claim/Inference: The contrasting results imply naps and increased nighttime sleep are not equivalent substitutes in this setting; instrumented per-minute analysis rejects equal per-minute effects of nap versus night sleep on the overall index and several families (naps more beneficial per minute for cognition, preferences, psychological well-being), though naps crowd out more labor per minute

Explanation/Claim: A plausible explanation for null night-sleep benefits is low sleep quality (low efficiency and fragmentation) in participants' home environments and/or that lab-induced severe deprivation effects do not generalize to marginal increases in sleep in field settings

Limitation: The intervention lasted a few weeks and cannot adjudicate long-run health or labor-market effects; external validity to other populations, longer durations, or different job settings remains an open question

Conclusion/Policy implication: In this urban poor Chennai context, increasing nighttime sleep by expanding time in bed yielded little short-run economic or cognitive benefit and had opportunity costs in labor supply, whereas short workplace naps improved cognition, well-being, and some productivity measures; policy extrapolations from lab evidence should be cautious and research should target improving sleep quality and longer-run effects
